sen.j: 宗祇（そうぎ、1421年（応永28年）－1502年9月1日（文亀2年7月30日 (旧暦)））は、室町時代の連歌師。
sen.e: Sogi (1421－September 1, 1502 (July 30, Bunki 2nd (old calendar)) was a renga (linked-verse) poet of the Muromachi period.
Sogi (1421－September 1, 1502 (July 30, Bunki 2 (old calendar)) was a renga (linked-verse) poet of the Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: I think "Bunki 2" is a more common translation so I used that.
sen.e: Sogi (1421－September 1, 1502) was a renga (linked-verse) poet of the Muromachi period.
His literary names were Jinensai and Shugyokuan.

sen.j: 姓は飯尾というが定かではない。
sen.e: His family name was said to be IIO, but it is still unclear.

sen.j: 生国は、紀伊国とも近江国とも言われている。
sen.e: His birthplace was said to be in Kii or Omi province.

sen.j: 若いころ京都相国寺に入り、30歳のころ連歌に志したという。
sen.e: He entered Shokoku-ji Temple in Kyoto in his youth, and made up his mind to pursue renga at the age of around 30.

sen.j: 宗砌、専順、心敬に連歌を学び、東常縁に古今伝授を授けられた。
sen.e: He studied renga under Sozei, Senjun and Shinkei, and was given the transmission of the secret traditions of the Kokinshu (Kokin Denju) by Tsuneyori TO.
He studied renga under Sozei, Senjun and Shinkei, and received instruction in the secret traditions of the Kokinshu (Kokin Denju) by Tsuneyori TO.
sen.cmt: I personally think that "given the transmission" sounds a bit off in this context, so I replaced it with "received instruction in"
sen.e: He studied renga under Sozei, Senjun and Shinkei, and received instruction in the secret traditions of the Kokinshu (Kokin Denju) by Tsuneyori TO.

sen.j: 1473年（文明 (日本)5年）以後、公家や将軍、管領の居住する上京（かみきょう）に種玉庵を結び、三条西実隆他の公家や細川政元他の室町幕府の上級武士と交わった。
sen.e: After 1473, he made his residence at Shugyokuan in Kamikyo (Upper Kyoto), where court nobles, the shogun and the kanrei (shogunal deputy) lived, associating with Sanetaka SANJONISHI and other court nobles, and Masamoto HOSOKAWA and other high-ranking warriors of the Muromachi shogunate.

sen.cmt: Removed the extraneous "and" before "Masamoto". Added "as well as" to make it read a bit smoother.

sen.cmt: shogunate→bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)

sen.j: また、畿内の有力国人衆や周防国の大内氏、若狭国の武田氏、越後国の上杉氏ら各地の大名をたずねている。
sen.e: He also visited powerful local lords (kokujin) in the Kinai area and the daimyo of many provinces, such as the Ouchi clan in Suo province, the Takeda clan in Wakasa province, and the Uesugi clan in Echigo province.

sen.j: 1488年（長享2年）北野連歌所宗匠となり、名実ともに連歌界の第一人者となった。
sen.e: In 1488, he was appointed as the Renga Master of Kitano Shrine and became both in name and reality the leading figure in renga circles
In 1488, he was appointed as the Renga Master of Kitano Shrine and became the leading figure in renga circles in both name and reality.
sen.cmt: Moved "both in name and reality" to the end of the sentence and rewrote it as "in both" as this sounds a little more natural to me.
sen.e: In 1488, he was appointed as the Renga Master of Kitano Shrine and became the leading figure in renga circles in both name and reality.

sen.j: この職は、まもなく兼載に譲り、1495年（明応4年）兼載らと『新撰菟玖波集』を編集した。
sen.e: He soon ceded this post to Kensai and compiled the "New Tsukuba Collection" (Shinsen Tsukubashu) with Kensai and others in 1495.
He soon ceded this post to Kensai and compiled the "New Tsukuba Collection" (Shinsen Tsukubashu) with Kensai and others in 1495.

sen.j: 生涯を通じ、たびたび各地を旅したが、1502年弟子の宗長、宗碩らに伴われて越後から美濃国に向かう途中、箱根温泉の旅館で没し、駿河国桃園（現：静岡県裾野市）定輪寺に葬られた。
sen.e: He traveled frequently to various parts of the country throughout his life, and in 1502, he died at an inn at the Hakone hotsprings while on the way from Echigo to Mino province with his disciples Socho and Soseki, and was buried at Jorin-ji Temple at Momozono, Suruga Province (the present Susono City, Shizuoka Prefecture).

sen.j: 応仁の乱以後、古典復興の気運が高まり、地方豪族、特に国人領主層に京都文化への関心と連歌の大流行が見られた。
sen.e: After the Onin war, there was a growing trend towards a revival of the classics, and powerful local clans, especially local lords and lords of fiefs, were interested in the culture of Kyoto and remarkably enthusiastic about renga.

sen.j: 宗祇は、連歌本来の伝統である技巧的な句風に『新古今和歌集』以来の中世の美意識である「長（たけ）高く幽玄にして有心（うしん）なる心」を表現した。
sen.e: Sogi expressed the technical skill of the original renga tradition, and what had been the medieval sense of beauty ever since the "Shinkokin wakashu": 'lofty, sublime, true'.
Sogi expressed the technical skill of the original renga tradition, and the medieval aesthetics of sublimity and truth expressed in the waka poetry anthology Shikokin Wakashu.
sen.cmt: Reworded "and what had been the medieval sense of beauty ever since the "Shinkokin wakashu": 'lofty, sublime, true'." to read a little clearer. Added brief explanation for Shikokin Wakashu.
sen.e: Sogi expressed the technical skill of the original renga tradition, and the medieval aesthetics of sublimity and truth expressed in the waka poetry anthology "Shinkokin Wakashu."

sen.j: 全国的な連歌の流行とともに、宗祇やその一門の活動もあり、この時代は連歌の黄金期であった。
sen.e: Along with renga's being popular throughout the country, and the activities of Sogi and his disciples, this period was the golden age of renga.

sen.j: 連歌の作品として『水無瀬三吟百韻』、『湯山三吟百韻』、『葉守千句』があり、句集に『萱草』（わすれぐさ）、『老葉』（わくらば）、『下草』（したくさ）、紀行文に『白河紀行』、『筑紫道記』（つくしみちのき）、連歌論に『吾妻問答』、『浅茅』などがあり、古典の注釈書も多い。
sen.e: Among his works there are for renga "Three poets at Minase" (Minase Sangin Hyakuin), "Three poets at Yuyama" (Yuyama Sangin Hyakuin), and "Hamori senku", also the collections of renga stanzas "Wakuraba" (Aging Leaves) and "Shitakusa" (The Grasses Beneath); for travel records "Shirakawa kiko" (Journey to Shirakawa) and "Tsukushi michi no ki" (Record of a Journey to Tsukushi), for treatises on renga poetry "East Country Dialogues" (Azuma mondo) and "Asaji" (Cogon grass), etc., and there are also many commentaries on classic literature.
sen.cmt: 『葉守千句』→google book上の英語文献(２件）では、タイトルの英訳はなされていないようでした。『筑紫道記』→引用は"Tsukushi no michi no ki"となっていましたが、本文は原文にあわせて「の」を省きました。

sen.j: 和歌の西行、俳句の松尾芭蕉とともに連歌を代表する漂泊の人である。
sen.e: He is another wandering poet, representative of renga poetry like Saigyo for waka and Basho MATSUO for haiku.
